metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: You can loop through the array elements with the for loop.
content.html: You can loop through the array elements with the for loop.

content.text: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array:
content.html: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array:

content.code_html:
// Create an array of strings
string cars[5] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda", "Tesla"};

// Loop through strings
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  cout << cars[i] << "\n";
}

content.text: This example outputs the index of each element together with its value:
content.html: This example outputs the index of each element together with its value:

content.code_html:
string cars[5] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda", "Tesla"};
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  cout << i << " = " << cars[i] << "\n";
}

content.text: And this example shows how to loop through an array of integers:
content.html: And this example shows how to loop through an array of integers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
int myNumbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {  
  cout << myNumbers[i] << "\n";}

content.code:
int myNumbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
cout << myNumbers[i] << "\n";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
int myNumbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {  
  cout << myNumbers[i] << "\n";}

content.code_html:
int myNumbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  cout << myNumbers[i] << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
int myNumbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {  
  cout << myNumbers[i] << "\n";}

content.text: There is also a " for-each loop" (introduced in C++ version 11 (2011)), which is used exclusively to loop through elements in an array (and other data structures, like vectors and lists ):
content.html: There is also a "for-each loop" (introduced in C++ version 11 (2011)), which is used exclusively to loop through elements in an array (and other data structures, like vectors and lists):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
for (type variableName : arrayName) {  // code block to be executed
  }

content.code:
for (type variableName : arrayName) {  // code block to be executed
}

syntax_highlighting.text:
for (type variableName : arrayName) {  // code block to be executed
  }

content.code_html:
for (type variableName : arrayName) {
  // code block to be executed
 }

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
for (type variableName : arrayName) {  // code block to be executed
  }

content.text: The following examples output all elements in an array using a " for-each loop":
content.html: The following examples output all elements in an array using a "for-each loop":

content.code_html:
// Create an array of integers
int myNumbers[5] = {10, 20, 30, 40, 50};

// Loop through integers
for (int i : myNumbers) {
  cout << i << "\n";
}

// Create an array of strings
string cars[5] = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda", "Tesla"};

// Loop through strings
for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
How do you access the elements in an array using a for loop?
content.html: How do you access the elements in an array using a for loop?

metadata.question: How do you access the elements in an array using a for loop?

options.text: By using the array index inside square brackets
By using parentheses around the element

By using parentheses around the element
